dn33:3.2.43: Nine lost opportunities for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.44: Firstly, a Realized One has arisen in the world. He teaches the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One.

dn33:3.2.47: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.48: But a person has been reborn in the animal realm.
dn33:3.2.49: This is the second lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.50: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.51: But a person has been reborn in the ghost realm.
dn33:3.2.52: This is the third lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.53: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.54: But a person has been reborn among the demons.
dn33:3.2.55: This is the fourth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.56: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.57: But a person has been reborn in one of the long-lived orders of gods.
dn33:3.2.58: This is the fifth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.59: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.60: But a person has been reborn in the borderlands, among strange barbarian tribes, where monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen do not go.
dn33:3.2.61: This is the sixth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.62: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.63: And a person is reborn in a central country. But they have wrong view and distorted perspective:
dn33:3.2.64: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. dn33:3.2.65: This is the seventh lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.66: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.67: And a person is reborn in a central country. But they’re witless, dull, stupid, and unable to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.
dn33:3.2.68: This is the eighth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.69: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn33:3.2.70: But he doesn’t teach the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One. And a person is reborn in a central country. And they’re wise, bright, clever, and able to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.
dn33:3.2.71: This is the ninth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.73: A mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn33:3.3.10: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.13: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.14: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.
dn33:3.3.16: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.17: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.
dn33:3.3.19: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.20: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.
dn33:3.3.22: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.23: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
dn33:3.3.25: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.26: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
dn33:3.3.28: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.29: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
dn33:3.3.31: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.32: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
dn33:3.3.34: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
dn33:3.3.36: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
dn33:3.3.37: They perceive the meditation on universal water …
dn33:3.3.45: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
dn33:3.3.46: Ten ways of doing unskillful deeds:
dn33:3.3.47: killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.
dn33:3.3.48: Ten ways of doing skillful deeds:
dn33:3.3.49: refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; refraining from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.
dn33:3.3.51: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.
dn33:3.3.52: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?
dn33:3.3.53: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
dn33:3.3.54: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.
dn33:3.3.55: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?
dn33:3.3.56: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
dn33:3.3.57: Hearing a sound with their ears … Smelling an odor with their nose … Tasting a flavor with their tongue … Feeling a touch with their body …
dn33:3.3.58: Knowing a thought with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
dn33:3.3.59: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.
dn33:3.3.60: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?
dn33:3.3.61: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.
dn33:3.3.62: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.
dn33:3.3.63: And how does a mendicant have four supports?
dn33:3.3.64: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.
dn33:3.3.65: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.
dn33:3.3.66: And how has a mendicant eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?
dn33:3.3.67: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. A mendicant has dispelled, eliminated, thrown out, rejected, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.
dn33:3.3.68: That’s how a mendicant has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.
dn33:3.3.69: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?
dn33:3.3.70: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.
dn33:3.3.71: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.
dn33:3.3.72: And how does a mendicant have unsullied intentions?
dn33:3.3.73: It’s when they’ve given up sensual, malicious, and cruel intentions.
dn33:3.3.74: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.
dn33:3.3.75: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?
dn33:3.3.76: It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
dn33:3.3.77: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.
dn33:3.3.78: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?
dn33:3.3.79: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.
dn33:3.3.80: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.
dn33:3.3.81: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?
dn33:3.3.82: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’
dn33:3.3.85: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.
dn33:3.3.87: an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.
dn33:3.3.88: Reverends, these are the teachings grouped by ten that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.
dn33:3.3.89: You should all recite these in concert, without disputing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
dn33:3.4.1: Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Sāriputta,
dn33:3.4.3: It’s good that you’ve taught this exposition of the reciting in concert.”
dn33:3.4.4: That is what Venerable Sāriputta said, and the teacher approved.
dn33:3.4.5: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Sāriputta said.
